subtitles.transcript: One of the problems with (the BP contract) as well as the Novartis deal is:
Who’s getting executive control over what gets researched? Who’s choosing what projects are fundable and interesting?
And instead of having a broader scientific community say, “These are the interesting scientific questions,” it’s a private industry
saying, “These are the questions, because these are the ones that are interesting to us and our profit-making.”
So that’s like a major sort of scientific problem about “Where is science going to go?”
and “How is science being directed by interests oriented towards profit-making and extraction of limited resources
on the earth?” Fundamentally, this undermines the public mission of the university, and that’s
one of the sort of, for me, the core dangers — is that having research funded
by private industry oriented towards their private interests is not — it’s very different than the
public interest. Sort of conflating private interests and public interests is a major problem.
